Title: Continuous EEG Monitoring in Neonates with Congenital Heart Disease: A Retrospective Cohort Study

Background: This study investigates the impact of continuous EEG (cEEG) background patterns and the duration of cross-clamp time and cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) on neurodevelopmental outcomes in neonates with congenital heart disease (CHD) undergoing cardiac surgery.

Methods: Conducted at Cleveland Clinic Children’s Hospital, Ohio, USA, this retrospective cohort study included infants with CHD who underwent surgery by 44 weeks gestational age and had cEEG monitoring. The primary outcome was neurodevelopmental scores on the Bayley Scales of Infant and Toddler Development (BSID-III) at 12–24 months.

Results: The study included 34 patients, with surgery performed at a median age of 7 days. Longer cross-clamp time was associated with poor language composite scores (p = 0.036). Severity of encephalopathy during the 24-hour post-operative period was significantly associated with poor language composite scores (p = 0.026). All neonates had below average cognitive, language, and motor composite scores on BSID-III. The study found a 100% rate of neurological abnormalities, with developmental delay and microcephaly being the most common.

Interpretation: The findings suggest that longer cross-clamp time and severe encephalopathy during the 24-hour post-operative period are linked to poor language outcomes in neonates with CHD. These results underscore the importance of early identification and intervention for high-risk infants to improve neurodevelopmental outcomes. Further research is needed to explore the relationship between EEG findings and long-term outcomes in this population.
